data.title: Zombie extension host
data.body: Write an extension that does `while(true);` and run it. Restart VS Code and notice you have zombie extension host process running forever on your system.

data.title: Make the code doc floating panel closable using the escape key

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: OSX 10.12 (Sierra)

When using Typescript, the floating code documentation window will pop up and float above the code, but I cannot close it using (naturally) the escape key. I have to use the mouse to click somewhere within the code window to then hide the popup, which is more effort and hinders typing efficiency.

It would be nice if the escape key could be used to hide this popup.

Example of the popup that I'm talking about:

![screen shot 2016-11-23 at 13 41 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/766403/20563936/9c8196fc-b182-11e6-9fdd-76020f09851b.png)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. When using Typescript, type some code that would access some imported class or object which has documentation comments associated with it
2. Observe that the popup cannot be closed using the escape key

data.title: Closing the find widget via x does not clear find in selection toggle
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

The selection area of find/replace keeps popping up even after I close the dialog find/replace by pressing the 'close' button.

PS: When the document is not saved, the expected behavior occurs.
When I press ESC the expected behavior also occurs. Only when the document is saved does this bug occur.

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open New Document
2.  Paste:
Test Select
Test Select
Test Select
Test Select

3.  Save document
4.  Press Ctrl + A
5.  Press Ctrl + F
6.  In Dialog Find/Replace press  button 'Find in Selection'
7.  Press button 'Close' in right of 'Find in Selection'

Steps to reproduce expected:

4.  Press Ctrl + A
5.  Press Ctrl + F
6.  In Dialog Find/Replace press  button 'Find in Selection'
7.  Press ESC

data.title: Fix focus and configuration handling of the integrated terminal
data.body:
This PR fixes 2 problems with the focus handling of the integrated terminal (see #15103 and #14969) .  

Although they result in a  same usability/keybinding problem I initially described in #15103, my description was a little fuzzy because I didn't understand the cause fully. 

There are currently 2 problems:

---

**Problem Nr. 1**

Whenever a second (or third, …) terminal instance gets exited via the shell command `exit` or by pressing `ctrl-d` (which basically is "exit" because it sends EOF), the terminal panel loses focus and the editor gets focus.

This hinders the workflow when working with multiple terminals, because you can't close a second one without refocusing the panel again, worst case scenario would be that a user write `exit` into an editor window without being aware of it.

The only case where focus has to change is if there is only 1 instance left, in this case the panel closes itself so the user has a visual clue about whats going on.

Just in case anyone asks, the reasoning I used [focus(true)](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/19f86525f2b1fc7d87f0ad6b26c3c6524336f807/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalService.ts#L131) in [setActiveInstanceByIndex()](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/19f86525f2b1fc7d87f0ad6b26c3c6524336f807/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalService.ts#L125) instead of inside [_removeInstance()](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/19f86525f2b1fc7d87f0ad6b26c3c6524336f807/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalService.ts#L99) just in case there are some edge cases I didn't stumble upon yet. I'd guess you always want to focus your active instances, but correct me if I'm wrong.

---

**Problem Nr. 2**

To make the terminal work with various keyboard shortcuts, the setting `terminal.integrated.commandsToSkipShell` was introduced. The first part of my Issue I described in #15103 and I later found out to be described in #14969 as well is caused by the following:

Currently, the settings are only handled in the panel itself when [_updateCommandsToSkipShell()](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/19f86525f2b1fc7d87f0ad6b26c3c6524336f807/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalPanel.ts#L263) is called (whenever the panel gets opened). If you create a new instance with either the `+`-Button in the GUI or via a shortcut, a new terminal instance get's created, gets attached – but [_skipTerminalKeybindings](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/19f86525f2b1fc7d87f0ad6b26c3c6524336f807/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalInstance.ts#L122) is empty.

Calling the function to skip the commands from inside [TerminalService#createInstance()](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/19f86525f2b1fc7d87f0ad6b26c3c6524336f807/src/vs/workbench/parts/terminal/electron-browser/terminalService.ts#L62) made most sense to me because it's already aware of the settings, but correct me again if I'm wrong with this assumption.

data.title: Add workspaces with backups to the list of folders to open
data.body:
@Tyriar an attempt to fix https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15274. Basically simplifies the initial startup by just treating workspaces with backups as folders to open. This will still allow users to open individual files within the folders.

However, currently blocked by https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15718 because in order to still restore the backups from a previous session, `backupRestorer.ts` has to know which files have backups. Today `backupRestorer.ts` purely relies on the editor stacks model to restore the files, but in the case of opening individual files from CLI, the editor stacks model does not restore.

data.title: LESS: Import-Options only allow one option, Spec allows multiple

1.  Create a .less-File
2. Enter the following code;
`@import (once,less) url("fonts/someStyleSheet.css");`

VSCode will notify you with:
`[less] ) expected`
Less-Reference: Less-Reference: http://lesscss.org/features/#import-options however allows multiple Import-Options

data.title: [less] parent selector "&" hover does not correctly work

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Enterprise
I am not using any additional LESS-Linting Plugins

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Create a .less-File
2. Enter the following code:
```
.foo {
    &__bar {
        width:100%
    }
}
```
3. Hover over "__bar"

It is now shown as: `<undefined__bar class="foo">` while it should be correctly shown as `<undefined class="foo__bar">`

Reference here: http://lesscss.org/features/#parent-selectors-feature

data.title: text editor insert snippet API
data.body: Since we have now a `SnippetString` it would also be beneficial to allow snippets to inserted into the editor. Similar to `TextEditor.edit` we should have something that allows inserting a snippet string and bringing the editor into snippet mode.

data.title: Doesn't seem to automatically find index.d.ts for imports of depth 2 (or more)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 8

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Import something from node_modules/<module>/<folder 1>/<folder 2> within a file, e.g. 'import { inject, TestBed }  from "@angular/core/testing"'.
2. VSCode keeps saying cannot find module, yet executing the transpiled source works as expected.

Can resolve it if I explicitly specify index.d.ts:

'import { inject, TestBed }  from "@angular/core/testing/index".

I'm also using node moduleResolution and every other import works fine.

data.title: Check and clean up backup workspaces that don't have any files backed up on launch
data.body:
@Tyriar this is an attempt to fix https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15499

Basically on startup the backup main service validates each workspace path in the `workspaces.json` has a valid backup state. Valid backups are:
* backup folder exists
* backup folder contains folders per schema (file, untitled)
* backup folder per schema contains entries

If the validation finds out the workspace path has no valid backup, it is removed from `workspaces.json` as well as deleted from the backups folder. 

This also means we no longer need to update `workspaces.json` on quit because we do the clean up on startup anyways.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f, 2016-11-21T22:06:37.428Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|theme-toothpaste|aalaap|0.0.1|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.10.0|
|one-monokai|azemoh|0.1.15|
|vscode-icontheme-nomo-dark|be5invis|1.1.5|
|plsql|casian|0.0.2|
|theme-dracula|dracula-theme|1.2.5|
|theme-spacemacs|dzannotti|0.0.8|
|vscode-turtle|feihuangtengda|1.0.30|
|Theme-Carbonight|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-CloudsMidnight|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-Dreamweaver|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-Eiffel|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-Frontier|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-Hyrule|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-TwoStones|gerane|0.0.2|
|Theme-Wildlife-Day|gerane|0.0.2|

Steps to Reproduce:

1) open two files
2) collapse some large portions of code in file 1
3) click e.g. on first line in file 1
4) scroll down few screens in file 1
5) switch to file 2
6) switch back to file 1
7) you will be scrolled (focused) to a wrong position, different from where you were before the switch

data.title: "stdout maxBuffer exceeded" error (with launch.json - processId settings)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.2 (1.7.2)
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.3
- Node Version: on 4.4.7 or 6.9.1

### Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Setup launch.json with following settings
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/app.js",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}"
        },
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "Attach to Process",
            "port": 5858,
            "processId": "${command.PickProcess}"
        }
    ]
}
```
2. Launch node app.js successfully (using nodemon)
3. Start debugging in "Attach to Process" mode

Result: "stdout maxBuffer exceeded" error message is thrown
Workaround: specify process Id with hard-coded value

data.title: (feature request) Smart Horizontal Scrolling

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

My suggestion is when (vertical) scrolling a long file with a deep indentation, the relevant text will be "hidden" because with the indentation, the text will more and more to right position of the screen. Then we need "stop" the vertical scrolling, scroll a little to right to see the full text (or most of), and we can start working on that. Then if we want vertical scroll to top or bottom, the text will indent (sometimes to right, sometime to left...), you will need, again, stop the vertical scrolling, adjust the viewport scrolling to right or left, and then go on with vertical scrolling.

Look a little example:

                                                                                  _`VSCode must Smart Scroll in order to you see this text. Its not hard detect that the left side of the screen is full of tabs or whitespaces, and the actual code is here, on the right side. `_

My idea is simple, you does vertical scrolling and the VSCode can "detect" that you are seeing... nothing, the text was indented far right, so VSCode will "smart scroll" to right or left to show the actual text in that point.

data.title: Synchronize changes failed because the remote branch can not be fetched.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04.3 LTS, Trusty Tahr
- Git Version: 2.10.1

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Push a new branch to remote successfully
2. Delete the remote branch
3. Edit something local and commit it.
4. Click sync button.
5. VSCode alert error "There was an issue running a git operation. Please review the output or use a console to check the state of your repository."

In output I can find "Your configuration specifies to merge with the ref 'refs/heads/bugfix'
from the remote, but no such ref was fetched.". To resolve the problem, I have to run git push in command line to create the remote branch.

Should it use git push automatically? Or change the button from sync to cloud upload in the status bar to tell user the remote branch is not existed?

![vscode-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4801955/20549785/6ccf5ed4-b16a-11e6-9769-33a363ef06a1.jpg)

data.title: multiple background colors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: mac os 10.12.1
![screen shot 2016-11-22 at 9 21 48 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/508936/20549462/5d784416-b0fa-11e6-9a35-9ee9ba3a7f43.png)


The bounds of the editor view that contain text are a darker background color than the bounds that do not. Is this by design or am I seeing things?


Steps to Reproduce: 

1.  open any file with some text present or create a new file.
2. use a high resolution screen or low zoom level to view the file.
3. use any included theme - seems to reproduce in all, but harder to see in light themes.

data.title: Option + Left/Right/Delete don't work in the terminal window
data.body:
The terminal window is great. However, the navigation shortcuts to navigate one word forward or back don't appear to work. Instead of jumping forward and back one word, they print the following characters:

* Option + Left: `;5D`
* Option + Right: `;5C`

Option + Delete also doesn't delete a word at a time, and instead just behaves as a regular Delete, deleting one character at a time.

These shortcuts work normally in regular text boxes (e.g. here on GitHub) or in macOS Terminal when "Use Option as Meta key" is enabled.

Environment:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.1
